title: External packages that don't work without loading modules
body:
A lot of external packages are not built with RPATH support, and so they need `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` to be set in order to use them. However, even if you specify which module needs to be loaded in `packages.yaml`, this env var is blown away.

### Steps to reproduce the issue

packages.yaml:
```yaml
packages:
    python:
        modules:
            python@3.7.0%gcc@7.2.0: python/3
            python@2.7.15%gcc@7.2.0: python/2
        buildable: False
```
```console
$ spack install py-setuptools
==> python@3.7.0 : externally installed in /usr/local/python/3.7.0
==> python@3.7.0 : generating module file
==> python@3.7.0 : registering into DB
==> Installing py-setuptools
==> Searching for binary cache of py-setuptools
==> Warning: No Spack mirrors are currently configured
==> No binary for py-setuptools found: installing from source
/usr/local/python/3.7.0/bin/python3.7: error while loading shared libraries: libpython3.7m.so.1.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
==> Error: ProcessError: Command exited with status 127:
    '/usr/local/python/3.7.0/bin/python3.7' '-c' 'from distutils.sysconfig import get_config_var; print(get_config_var('"'"'LIBDIR'"'"'))'
```
The module file is pretty simple:
```console
$ module show python/3
-------------------------------------------------------------------
/usr/local/modulefiles/python/3:

module-whatis	 python 3.7.0 
module		 load gcc/7.2.0 
prepend-path	 PATH /usr/local/python/3.7.0/bin 
prepend-path	 NLTK_DATA /usr/local/python/3/data 
prepend-path	 PYTHONPATH /usr/local/python/3.7.0/lib/python3.7/site-packages 
prepend-path	 LD_LIBRARY_PATH /usr/local/python/3.7.0/lib 
prepend-path	 MANPATH /usr/local/python/3.7.0/share/man 
-------------------------------------------------------------------
```
We either need to start loading these module files, or at least allow explicit `environment:` options in `packages.yaml` like we do in `compilers.yaml`. The only current workaround is to use `spack install --dirty`.
